abstract.t: This document describes a BMP session lifecycle extension to prevent data duplication of re-exporting previously exported metrics when BMP session is re-established. It prevents loss of metrics between BMP session re-establishments to increase overall BMP scalability and reduces the possible loss of metrics to a minimum.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: With the constant increase of BGP paths, the increase of BMP BGP RIB coverage from RFC8671 and draft-ietf-grow-bmp-local-rib, the addition of new TLV's such as draft-cppy-grow-bmp-path-marking-tlv and draft-xu-grow-bmp-route-policy-attr-trace, more BGP metrics and metric dimensions are exported from BMP client to server.

With each BMP session re-establishment, BMP exports the initial BGP RIB with BMP route-monitoring messages as described in section 5 of RFC7854. Regardless if the same metrics where already exported in a previous BMP session or not. This leads to data duplication and unnecessary strain of the BMP client and server.

Most times in a network operators network, the BMP session is re-established within a short period of time due to connectivity interruption or restart of the BMP server due to maintenance. Even though, most BMP client implementations support a BMP buffer mechanism, metrics are not buffered across BMP session re-establishment, thus leading to a loss of metrics.
Therefore, the proposed BMP session lifecycle improvement covers

list.t: Brief loss of connectivity between BMP client and server

section.t: It is based on RFC7413, TCP Fast Open, which allows previously established TCP transport sessions to be re-established more efficiently.
This draft describes how the BMP application MUST behave during TCP transport re-establishment period in order to prevent metric loss.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

t.hangText: Brief loss of connectivity between BMP client and server:

list.t: Describes a period of time in seconds starting from where the BMP client detects loss of connectivity to the BMP server and tries to re-establish the TCP session.
Describes a period of time in seconds starting from where the BMP server daemon is restarted for maintenance purposes and BMP client tries to re-establish the TCP session.

section.title: BMP Client and Server Capability
section.t: To support brief loss of connectivity between BMP client and server, the BMP client and server MUST support TCP Fast Open as described in RFC7413.

To support seamless maintenance of BMP server, the BMP client and server MUST support TCP Fast Open as described in RFC7413 and the restart of the BMP server MUST distinguish between normal and seamless restart, wherever TCP Fast Open cookies are preserved or not.

section.title: Updated BMP Session Lifecycle
section.t: Section 3 of RFC7413 describes the TCP Fast Open extension in the initial TCP SYN packet and the cookie handling during initial and subsequent re-establishment of the TCP transport session.
Section 3.3 of RFC7854 describes that the BMP session closes with the TCP session. This behavior is extended with a configurable BMP session timeout.
The BMP session timeout starts counting down under the following conditions:

list.t: Current TCP session was established with Fast Open extension and cookie has been saved
TCP session is going to be terminated

section.t: The default BMP session timeout is 60 seconds.
While the time is counting down, all the BMP messages, regardless of message type, MUST be buffered. At this stage, the BMP session is still considered to be alive.

When TCP session is re-established with TCP Fast Open extension and cookie is identically to previous TCP session, the BMP session remain alive, BMP buffer is being exported and normal operation continues.

When TCP session is re-established without TCP Fast Open extension or with TCP Fast Open extension but cookie is not identically to previous TCP session, the BMP session is considered terminated and starts with a new BMP initiation message.
When TCP session is not re-established within configured BMP timeout, than BMP buffer is discarded and BMP session is considered terminated.
When BMP buffer is full before TCP session is re-established, than BMP buffer is discarded and BMP session is considered terminated.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The same security considerations apply as for TCP Fast Open RFC7413.
